Award.AwardTitle: Chronotype differences in the acute behavioral responses to light and darkness and their neural subtracts
Award.AbstractNarration: The rhythmic daily patterning of activity and rest is a fundamental feature of virtually all forms of vertebrate life, including our own, and is heavily influenced by light. Light has very different effects on day-active and night-active species, with the former responding to darkness by increasing sleep and the latter responding with a decrease. Very little is known about the brain mechanisms mediating these effects of light on rest/sleep, and essentially nothing is known about how these mechanisms differ among day-and night-active species. The research to be undertaken in this project will begin to fill this gap in our fundamental understanding of these issues suing multiple approaches. First the behavioral responses to light will be directly compared in nocturnal and diurnal rodents, then the neural mechanisms mediating those responses will be characterized. The work will determine how specific populations of cells in the brain are affected by the changes in lighting conditions that affect rest and activity, and the role that these structures play in the process will then evaluated experimentally. The project outcomes could yield fundamental new insights into processes that have a profound impact on the lives of day-active animals including humans. A better basic understanding of these issues will lead to improved strategies to help the millions of Americans with sleep problems cope with them more effectively. Strategies that could be informed by the outcomes of this project include appropriately patterned administration of light, as well as, ultimately, new, safer and more effective pharmacological treatments. The project will also engage many undergraduate and graduate students in the research enterprise in ways that will provide them an inside view of how science is done.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our eyes are not just for seeing. In the retina, light excites a unique set of ganglion cells that is not involved in image formation, and that brings photic information to regions of the brain that do not participate in visual perception. This information about environmental illumination serves to synchronize or entrain our internally generated daily (circadian) rhythms to the day-night cycle, and as far as we know, this function is served by very similar mechanisms in night-active species and day-active ones, like our own. But in addition to synchronizing circadian rhythms, light can facilitate or inhibit sleep and general activity directly, via mechanisms that operate in parallel with the circadian regulation of those functions; this phenomenon is referred to as “masking”. It is looking at the masking effects of light on behavior when we see extreme contrasting features between diurnal and nocturnal species; light induces sleep in nocturnal animals, such as the laboratory rodents commonly used for neuroscientific research, whereas it enhances wakefulness and arousal in diurnal species including humans.  Clearly, for the full mechanistic understanding of the effects of masking on behavior a diurnal laboratory animal model is needed, particularly to generate insights that apply to our own species.  It is in this context that our work with the diurnal Nile grass rat (Arvicanthis niloticus) has made a contribution to the field of photobiology and has informed and guided other areas of behavioral neuroscience.

During the period of support by this award, we have published studies showing that under several experimental conditions the general activity of diurnal grass rats responds to intervals of light and darkness very differently, and often in direct opposition, from what nocturnal laboratory animals show. This work has thus validated the use of the grass rats as an animal model for the study of mechanisms that mediate the effects of light in diurnal species, and to investigate how those mechanisms differ in day-active vs night-active mammals. Interestingly, a subset of the normally diurnal grass rats of our colony switches to a nocturnal pattern of activity when given access to activity wheels in their home cages. When this happens their masking responses are affected in a fashion that makes them more like what is typically seen in nocturnal rodents. This suggests that humans that voluntarily become predominantly nocturnal due to life-style preferences or the demands of their jobs, may compromise their natural tendencies and show inappropriate responses to light and darkness, resulting in disruption of their sleep patterns.

To complement the behavioral studies, our group has used indices of neural activation in the brain to identify regions that respond differently to light in diurnal grass rats and nocturnal rodents. In addition, our anatomical studies of the connections between the cells in the retina that are critical for mediation of masking and particular areas of the brain have identified both similarities and clear differences between grass rats and nocturnal rodents. These observations served to guide a series of studies in which selective lesions were placed in different areas of the brain of grass rats, followed by systematic evaluation of masking responses to light. This work has served to identify components of a light-responsive neural system in a diurnal brain, with some regions mediating exclusively masking responses, others serving primarily circadian functions and yet others involved in both the circadian regulation of activity as well as the control of specie-specific masking responses to light.

The work supported by this award has provided the foundation for the use of the grass rats to investigate how light affects a variety of important functions that go beyond masking responses. Experiments using grass rats have now shown that light restriction can result in behavioral effects similar to those associated with humans suffering from seasonal affective disorders, and that exposure to dim illumination during the light phase of the cycle can have detrimental effects on learning and memory, as well as in the functioning of specific brain regions involved in neural and behavioral plasticity.

In addition to the direct scientific contributions made possible by this award, the work has provided a venue and resources for the training of undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows who have now moved on successfully to the next stages of their careers. Finally the grant support has been essential for the maintenance of a colony of grass rats at Michigan State University. Animals from this colony have been donated to various laboratories to conduct studies in a range of topics that benefit from the use of this unique diurnal animal model.
